Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Distributome--An Interactive Web-based Resource for Probability Distributions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a new computational and educational resource, the Distributome, for exploring, discovering and interacting with varieties of probability distributions. The Distributome project leverages the results of successful NSF projects that have been sustained over decades of work in developing interactive learning materials, forging technological advances, and building and sustaining digital libraries; all integrated with an effective dissemination and professional development infrastructure to ensure on-going use. There are several novel features of this project. This resource builds the infrastructure for community based development, expands and validates the distributions' meta-data that is stored, processed, searched, traversed and updated by experts, learners, and educators. The Distributome provides a graphical user interface for interactive exploration of diverse distribution resources, as well as a web-service for query, discovery and computational utilization of these distribution resources by other software programs and tools.

Specifically, this project provides an open (development and utilization), platform-agnostic, extensible and broad framework for navigation, discovery and usage of probability distributions in diverse applications. The entire framework is built using XML/JAVA/HTML/Wiki/MathML/LaTeX and is freely made available to the entire community via www.Distributome.org. The user-base of the Distributome infrastructure includes both educators (integrating these graphical tools and instructional materials in their course curricula and participating in a unique virtual community led by a cadre of activists) and most importantly learners (exploring, validating and understanding the use of probability distributions and models for practical problem solving). Probability modeling is at the root of solving driving biological, engineering, health, physical science, and social problems fundamental to the modern STEM curriculum. The Distributome infrastructure enables representation, demonstration, computation and visualization of a large number of probability distributions, their interrelations and their applications integrated with associated class and out-of-class activities to advance learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distributome (www.distributome.org) is a suite of web-based resources for students and teachers of probability and statistics, centered on probability distributions. The project consists of a number of interrelated components:

  • An interactive, graphical "navigator" with probability distributions represented as nodes and relations between the distributions as edges. A student can select a node and see the basic mathematical properties of the distribution represented by that node, or can select an edge and see the mathematical statement of the relation between the distributions connected by that edge. The distributions in the navigator can be filtered and searched in a number of different ways.
  • A collection of interactive web apps, including calculators, simulators, and experiments (enhanced simulators) for the most important and common probability distributions. The web apps illustrate probability distributions in graphical and numerical forms, and allow students to see the effects of varying the parameters of a distribution.
  • Several interactive games that help students with modeling and conceptual understanding. One game asks students to select the probability distribution that best governs a random variable in a simple applied problem. Other games ask students to match histograms from data to appropriate distributions.
  • A collection of activities (extended exercises) that explore important applied problems in probability and statistics from different points of view and using several different techniques. Many of the activities involve historically interesting data sets.

Underlying all of these components is a comprehensive database that encodes the mathematical properties of all of the important special probability distributions and the relations between these distributions.

The Distributome resources use standard (HTML5) technologies, and are accessible with any modern web browswer on a variety of platforms, from smart phones and tablets to laptop and desktop computers. The resources are free and open source, and the programming is explained through a number of technical documents available at the Distributome stie. Thus, teachers and students can not only use the resources, but can also adapt and modify them.

Probabililty and statistics are among the most important areas of mathematics, with deep connections in just about every subject that deals with quantification: the physical and biological sciences, engineering and technology, the social sciences, law, and medicine. Both the intellectual merit and the broader impact of the Distributome project derive from the high quality resources in the project that help students and teachers understand the randomness that is everywhere around us.
